properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first heat event of the season is expected today as a warm air mass moves over parts of Northwestern Ontario from the United States. Maximum daytime temperatures are expected to be near 30 degrees Celsius today with minimum temperatures tonight near 18 degrees Celsius. Cooler air is expected to arrive on Saturday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-07T23:06:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-06-07T15:07:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3211965766.2019
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Ear Falls - Perrault Falls - Western Lac Seul, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Wildfire Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: The Evacuation Alert for Marten Beach, Old Smith Highway, Mitsue, Poplar Lane, Fawcett Lake, Eben Road, Bayer Road and areas in the path of the McMillan Fire Complex in the Marten Hills has been lifted as of 9:00 am, June 7, 2019. The State of Local Emergency will expire at 11:22 am today. ### For more information on wildfire status go to srd.web.alberta.ca/slave-lake-area-update.
Expires: 2019-06-14T09:14:08-06:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snow over highway passes expected this morning A cold upper trough moving through British Columbia will give some late season flurries to the mountain passes and northern British Columbia this morning. Flurries are expected above 1300-1500m elevation, however flurries could briefly descend lower during periods of intense flurry activity. Most southern highway passes are forecast to receive about 2 to 5 cm of wet snow this morning with a locally higher amount up to 10 cm possible over the Okanagan Connector. Over northern BC, the Alaska Highway (Highway 97) from the Rocky Mountain foothills to the Liard River can also expect flurries this morning. Precipitation will change back to rain near noon as the airmass begins to warm. Motorists and those venturing outdoors are encouraged to be prepared for winter-like conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-07T20:09:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-06-07T12:10:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2762215806.2019
Area: Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snow over highway passes expected this morning A cold upper trough moving through British Columbia will give some late season flurries to the mountain passes and northern British Columbia this morning. Flurries are expected above 1300-1500m elevation, however flurries could briefly descend lower during periods of intense flurry activity. Most southern highway passes are forecast to receive about 2 to 5 cm of wet snow this morning with a locally higher amount up to 10 cm possible over the Okanagan Connector. Over northern BC, the Alaska Highway (Highway 97) from the Rocky Mountain foothills to the Liard River can also expect flurries this morning. Precipitation will change back to rain near noon as the airmass begins to warm. Motorists and those venturing outdoors are encouraged to be prepared for winter-like conditions. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first heat event of the season is expected today and Saturday as a warm air mass moves over parts of Northwestern Ontario from the United States. Maximum daytime temperatures are expected to be near 30 degrees Celsius both today and Saturday with minimum overnight temperatures near 18 degrees Celsius. Cooler air is expected to arrive on Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-07T23:57:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-06-07T07:58:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1494426548.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and torrential rain. A low pressure system tracking from southeastern Saskatchewan northeast toward the northern Interlake area of Manitoba has triggered strong to severe thunderstorms over southeastern Saskatchewan. This threat of thunderstorms will continue throughout the night as the system starts to tap into hot and humid air originating from the Dakotas. The threat for severe thunderstorms will diminish during the early morning hours. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-07T18:15:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-06-07T06:16:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3374216308.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will drop near the freezing mark overnight Friday night. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-08T07:09:43-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm continues. A weather system tracking through southern Alberta will continue to bring snow to the mountain parks regions today, before tapering off this evening. Banff and northern parts of Kananaskis are expected to see the highest snowfall amounts. Although these snowfall amounts may be highly variable, heavy wet snow on foliated trees may cause branches to break and have significant impacts to campers and those traveling by car on higher elevation roadways. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-06-08T08:29:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-06-07T16:30:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1044089697.2019

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High levels of air pollution are expected to continue due to smoke from forest fires very close to Pickle Lake. These conditions are likely to continue into the weekend. Smoke plumes from a forest fire near Pickle Lake have resulted in deteriorated air quality in the area. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-06-08T06:18:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Province of Ontario, 2019-06-07T14:19:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3447305371.2019
Area: Pickle Lake - Cat Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Province of Ontario

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Wildfire Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: Highway 697 from Range Road 185 to the La Crete Ferry remains closed. The La Crete Ferry Campground will also remain closed until further notice. Conditions have improved however; areas of the wildfire continue to be active and dangerous. ### An 8-hour evacuation alert remains in effect for the Town of High Level and the Dene Tha’ First Nation community of Bushe River. Parts of Mackenzie County immediately north and south of High Level will also remain under 8-hour evacuation alert, along with a portion of the Blue Hills/Tompkins area. The Mandatory Evacuation Order has been lifted effective immediately for the area of Blue Hills/Tompkins. The residents west of Range Road 185, north and south of Highway 697 can re-enter their homes but will remain on an 8-hour evacuation alert. An 8-hour evacuation alert remains in effect for the Town of High Level and the Dene Tha’ First Nation community of Bushe River. Parts of Mackenzie County immediately north and south of High Level will also remain under 8-hour evacuation alert, along with a portion of the Blue Hills/Tompkins area. For added information, listen to the local community radio or follow Mackenzie County Facebook page www.facebook.com/Mackenzie-County-262409787134568/ for more evacuation and County updates. For inquiries, please call the Mackenzie County Incident Command Centre at 780-927-3718 during regular office hours of 8:15 AM – 4:30 PM. More information is also available at: - Air Quality - Government of Canada – Public Weather Alerts for Alberta - http://weather.gc.ca/warnings/index_e.html?prov=ab can be found on this website. - Check https://511.alberta.ca/region/Northern%20Alberta#:Alerts for more information on road conditions. - Additional Wildfire information is also available at www.wildfire.alberta.ca website. - Government of Alberta www.emergency.alberta.ca website.
Expires: 2019-06-14T11:26:08-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Alberta Emergency Management Agency On Behalf of Mackenzie County, 2019-06-07T11:25:43-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-5821
Area: Mackenzie #23
properties.Author: Alberta Emergency Management Agency On Behalf of Mackenzie County

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High levels of air pollution are expected to continue due to smoke from forest fires. Smoke plumes from a forest fire east of Pikangikum have resulted in deteriorated air quality in the area. East or southeast winds will direct smoke toward Pikangikum today until winds become south this evening. The windshift this evening should direct the smoke away from Pikangikum. If you, or someone in your care, develop symptoms, reduce or reschedule strenuous outdoors activities where ever possible until the air quality improves. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-06-08T06:47:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Province of Ontario, 2019-06-07T14:48:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2374733015.2019
Area: Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Province of Ontario

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and torrential rain. A low pressure system tracking from southeastern Saskatchewan northeast toward the northern Interlake area of Manitoba has triggered strong to severe thunderstorms over southeastern Saskatchewan. The threat of severe thunderstorms over western Manitoba will diminish by mid morning, but may redevelop later this afternoon as a cold front approaches. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
